docs.snippet: Equal Treatment For Each Film?      Is the Walt Disney organization deliberately squelching the Oscar chances of ''Spirited Away,'' the Japanese animated feature that it is distributing in the United States, in favor of ''Lilo and Stitch,'' Disney...
docs.lead_paragraph: Equal Treatment For Each Film? Is the Walt Disney organization deliberately squelching the Oscar chances of ''Spirited Away,'' the Japanese animated feature that it is distributing in the United States, in favor of ''Lilo and Stitch,'' Disney's in-house production?
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; Disney's limited release of Japanese animated movie Spirited Away discussed in light of Disney's embarassment of riches for potential Oscar nominees for animated feature category; actor Harrison Ford and director Ron Shelton make unusual appearance before group of writers and editors in New York to pitch movie Hollywood Homicide; Paramount Pictures delays release of movie The Core, which features fictional space shuttle crash, in wake of Columbia disaster (M)

docs.snippet: A month into the PGA Tour season, Tiger Woods has not played, no American player has won, but there has been plenty to discuss.    With Woods still recovering from knee surgery in December, several players have stepped up their games. Ernie Els of...
docs.lead_paragraph: A month into the PGA Tour season, Tiger Woods has not played, no American player has won, but there has been plenty to discuss. With Woods still recovering from knee surgery in December, several players have stepped up their games. Ernie Els of South Africa has been the world's hottest player so far, winning three times worldwide, including the Tour's first two events, in Hawaii. Vijay Singh of Fiji, who turns 40 later this month, has looked better than ever, winning last month's Phoenix Open. And Mike Weir of Canada, without a victory in 2002, captured last weekend's Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, shooting five rounds of 67 or better.
docs.abstract: Tiger Woods is still sidelined one month into PGA Tour season, recovering from knee surgery; absence of Woods is giving players like Ernie Els and Vijay Singh chance to excel and win tournaments (M)

headline.main: With Woods Sidelined, The Field Is More Open

docs.snippet: As one half of the 1990's comedy duo ''The Jerky Boys,'' Kamal Ahmed once made his living placing crank phone calls to unsuspecting victims and releasing the results on CD's. He has now graduated to independent filmmaking, and his first fiction fi...
docs.lead_paragraph: As one half of the 1990's comedy duo ''The Jerky Boys,'' Kamal Ahmed once made his living placing crank phone calls to unsuspecting victims and releasing the results on CD's. He has now graduated to independent filmmaking, and his first fiction film as a director, ''God Has a Rap Sheet,'' opens today at the Pioneer Theater in the East Village, where it will play every Wednesday and Thursday this month at 9:20 p.m. In Mr. Ahmed's original screenplay, the crank caller is now God himself, who in the guise of a former literature professor (John Ford Noonan) on the alcoholic skids, appears in a downtown Manhattan police holding pen. There he needles a cross-section of combative New Yorkers into embracing their shared humanity.
docs.abstract: Dave Kehr reviews Kamal Ahmed film God Has a Rap Sheet; photo (M)

docs.snippet: In his penthouse suite, Shane Mosley watched snowboarders career down his 45-inch television screen. ''I love doing that when I'm up in camp,'' Mosley, a once-celebrated boxer whose career has gone downhill over the last year or so, said of snowbo...
docs.lead_paragraph: In his penthouse suite, Shane Mosley watched snowboarders career down his 45-inch television screen. ''I love doing that when I'm up in camp,'' Mosley, a once-celebrated boxer whose career has gone downhill over the last year or so, said of snowboarding. ''I went down two times, two and a half weeks ago.'' Snowboarding is a dangerous game for boxers. One tumble, a simple twisted ankle, and a payday of nearly $2 million this Saturday could have been jeopardized.
docs.abstract: Shane Mosely, after two losses to Vernon Forrest in 2002, will try to reignite his career when he fights Raul Marquez in junior middleweight bout, the outcome of which could result in rematch with Oscar De La Hoya; photo (M)

headline.main: Mosley Wants to Be King of the Hill

docs.snippet: The Oscar Wilde Bookshop in Greenwich Village, the oldest gay and lesbian bookstore in the country and one of two left in the city, has been sold and will not have to close, the new owner said yesterday.    The bookstore had been scheduled to clos...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Oscar Wilde Bookshop in Greenwich Village, the oldest gay and lesbian bookstore in the country and one of two left in the city, has been sold and will not have to close, the new owner said yesterday. The bookstore had been scheduled to close last month after its owner, Larry Lingle, said that it was losing money and that he could no longer afford to keep it open.
docs.abstract: Deacon Maccubbin, owner of Lambda Rising Bookstores in Washington, DC, will buy Oscar Wilde Bookshop in Greenwich Village, saving it from closing, as was announced in recent weeks; it is oldest gay and lesbian bookstore in country and one of two left in New York City; history of store discussed (M)

headline.main: Plot Twist for a Gay Bookstore: The Last Chapter Actually Isn't

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical records were released yesterday for a woman who accused St. John's forward Grady Reynolds of assault, Reynolds's lawyer said. In a morning hearing, Judge Steven W. Paynter of Queens Criminal Court said he was not releasing all the documents that Reynolds's lawyer, Oscar Holt, had sought.
docs.abstract: Judge Steven W Paynter releases some medical records of St John's University student Rachel Seager, who accused basketball player Grady Reynolds of assault; records could prove injuries Seager said she sustained at hands of Reynolds actually occurred earlier (S)

headline.main: A Ruling in the St. John's Case

docs.snippet: Martin Brodeur, the goalie for the Devils, appeared in his seventh consecutive All-Star Game yesterday and gave up only one goal on nine shots in one period for the Eastern Conference in a 6-5 loss to the Western Conference. That alone is a good s...
docs.lead_paragraph: Martin Brodeur, the goalie for the Devils, appeared in his seventh consecutive All-Star Game yesterday and gave up only one goal on nine shots in one period for the Eastern Conference in a 6-5 loss to the Western Conference. That alone is a good statistic in a no-check show. Now consider some facts and opinions that are more significant. With his name twice engraved on the Stanley Cup, Brodeur is one of the best of his era, among the elite of a generation of great French-Canadian goalies from Quebec. But there is one honor the 30-year-old Brodeur has not won but might soon earn: The Vézina trophy, which goes to the best goalie in the National Hockey League.
docs.abstract: Joe Lapointe On Hockey column discusses New Jersey Devils goalie Martin Brodeur, who has won two Stanley Cups and leads league in victories but has never won Vezina trophy for best NHL goalie (M)

docs.snippet: AS home values have soared in recent years and interest rates have fallen to their lowest levels in decades, record numbers of homeowners have refinanced their mortgages. While homeowners refinance to reduce their monthly payments or shorten the t...
docs.lead_paragraph: AS home values have soared in recent years and interest rates have fallen to their lowest levels in decades, record numbers of homeowners have refinanced their mortgages. While homeowners refinance to reduce their monthly payments or shorten the term of their mortgages, many also cash out part of their equity. Such borrowers are using this cash to pay off credit card debt, finance college educations, modernize their properties, buy second homes or even take exotic trips. In just the last two years, more than 15 million mortgages were refinanced, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. The refinancing amounted to nearly half of the $2.5 trillion of all mortgage debt outstanding.
docs.abstract: Homeowners are taking advantage of soaring home values and falling interest rates to refinance mortgages; in last two years, more than 15 million mortgages were refinanced, with homeowners nationwide taking out equity amounting to $174 billion in 2001 and 2002; Freddie Mac analysis for 2002 shows average refinanced mortgage has interest rate 1-1/8 percent lower than original mortgage; trend is welcomed by homeowners who are using equity to reduce monthly payments, shorten term of mortgage pay off debt or other expenses; photo; illustration; chart of equity cashed out in last ten years (L)

docs.snippet: MARSDEN HARTLEY is one of the great artists and certainly one of the most intriguing art historical subjects of all time. Tall, awkward, driven, with preternaturally visionary eyes and an eagle-like profile, he arrived in New York in 1899 at age 2...
docs.lead_paragraph: MARSDEN HARTLEY is one of the great artists and certainly one of the most intriguing art historical subjects of all time. Tall, awkward, driven, with preternaturally visionary eyes and an eagle-like profile, he arrived in New York in 1899 at age 22. He came from Lewiston, Me., where he was born in 1877, by way of Cleveland, already seasoned by solitude and a sense of his difference. That is to say, he knew he was gay and he had survived a childhood of nearly Dickensian proportions, including the early death of his mother, abandonment by his father and poverty that required him to leave school at 15 and work in a shoe factory. ''My childhood was vast with terror and surprise,'' he later wrote. But in true Dickensian fashion, rescue was at hand: a succession of sponsors and patrons attracted to his obvious talent and charisma. They invited him on summer retreats in Maine, where he began a lifelong immersion in literature and religious thought (Emerson, Thoreau, the James brothers and Whitman, his first idol). They enlisted painting teachers in Cleveland and paid for his study at the National Academy of Design in Manhattan. For several years he studied in New York and painted and taught painting in Maine, whose landscape was his first and last great subject. In 1909 he met Alfred Stieglitz, who immediately gave him an exhibition and made him a prominent member of the select circle of American Modernists he was cultivating and promoting -- Georgia O'Keeffe, John Marin, Arthur Dove and Charles Demuth among them.
docs.abstract: Roberta Smith reviews Marsden Hartley retrospective at Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford; photos (M)

headline.main: Marsden Hartley's World: A Body Electric
